on the model side of the equation you know we hear an awful lot about folks talking about fine-tuning
and I'll I'll be honest here more often than not I kind of hear folks using fine-tuning as a shortcut for all types
of customization this is where I kind of want to re-calibrate you know everyone's expectations and really kind of think
about where do we use one tool versus another fine-tuning is really good when
you want to introduce bias into the models towards a u maybe a particular
stylistic preference uh you might want to introduce bias towards a particular version of an AP or an SDK or you want
to teach the model a new language or a highly differentiated bit of codebase
that isn't well represented in the public domain right so where does that get used right what are some good examples so um when I talk about
introducing bias for particular version of an API or an SDK well these these models the generic models the
foundational models are trained on kind of a wash of all the public data out there in the world and so they tend to
produce results that are unbiased based upon the version of your jdk or what
version of react that you're using or what version of any kind of dependency and so if your organization your team
has a preference for a particular version of a jdk that's when you want to use fine tuning or let's imagine for a
moment that you're performing a migration from one version of a library to another you really want to bias the
model towards the destination version and so you might use fine-tuning there or let's say that you have an
organization that has a highly differentiated code base maybe you have a proprietary code language um sa's got
this thing called abap I've never coded it myself but I know it exists right it does it's not very well represented in
the world public code and so that's when fine tuning can help educate kind or teach the models about that language now
this is the fun part how do we do that right how do we actually do fine tuning because it's not just the recipes the
algorithms that you use for fine tuning but but it's really what data is it that you use in order to introduce that bias
right so categorically we really look at two different things right we look at
data that is in the repository itself right and so yes that is the code that
is in your main branch right but the code that's in your main branch it's all kind
of it all to the models looks equal right there's nothing that says this code is code we're proud of this is code
that H we wrote a little while ago we're not maybe not so proud of that anymore but it's still there and we'll get to
refactoring it one day right well and so what you want to do is you also want to introduce effectively your recency bias
right so that you're kind of reflecting the best practices as you and your team understand them today and so what we do
is we look at the pull request data we look at which pull requests are being merged today we give bias to those and
we don't just look at what's being merged today we also look at what's being kind of like weeded out as part of the code review process so if you've got
code that was submitted as part of the initial PR it is weeded out as part of the code review process that is now a
negative feedback loop that tells us don't bias for code that looks like that
and so we look at that side of the equation then we also look at essentially the the the use of the large
language models themselves because your developers they're you know you're probably submitting to two or three PRS
